Another study to examine microbes beyond their association with disease was conducted by Pasteur. In 1850, he began to investigate the productive role of bacteria in the agricultural processes of lactic and alcoholic fermentation.
18 In 1885, to understand the digestion processes of livestock, Pasteur fed various farmyard animals with food artificially devoid of the most common microorganisms, to eventually state that life without microbes would be impossible.
19 According to Robert Koch, the doubt as to whether microbes were merely pathologic arose during the Hamburg cholera epidemic in 1892, in which individuals carrying the pathogen appeared not to fall ill.
